title: Notion vs Todoist for Beginners
meta_description: Notion vs Todoist for beginners who want to track daily tasks without building databases, templates, or custom systems first.
constraint_lens: You want to list tasks and check them off immediately without building databases, templates, or custom systems first.

verdict.summary: Todoist wins for beginners who just want to list tasks and check them off. You can open the app and start typing without choosing a template or building structure. Notion typically requires creating a page, selecting a database, or designing a layout before tasks feel organized. If the user must design a system before adding tasks, Notion fails first.
verdict.decision_rule: If the user must design a system before adding tasks, Notion fails first.

sections.heading: Why this matters for Beginners
sections.content: You said you just want to list tasks and check them off without setup. When an app asks you to choose templates or configure properties, it slows your start. A ready made task list removes that first barrier.

bullets.point: Custom database tables with properties such as status and priority
bullets.why_it_matters: You can design your own task system, but you must decide on fields before it feels complete.

bullets.point: Templates that pre build task layouts
bullets.why_it_matters: You can start from a structure, yet choosing and modifying templates adds decisions.

bullets.point: Tasks embedded inside pages and workspaces
bullets.why_it_matters: You can combine notes and tasks, but setting up pages takes extra steps.

bullets.point: Immediate task entry field on first launch
bullets.why_it_matters: You can add a task without creating a system or layout.

bullets.point: Simple project lists that work without customization
bullets.why_it_matters: You can keep everything in one list and ignore advanced features.

bullets.point: Checkbox completion with no structural movement
bullets.why_it_matters: You mark tasks done without adjusting views or properties.

sections.heading: Where each tool can break down

items.fails_when: You feel stuck choosing templates or designing properties before writing tasks.
items.what_to_do_instead: Use Todoist if you want instant task entry with no setup.

items.fails_when: You later want tasks deeply connected to notes and custom views.
items.what_to_do_instead: Use Notion if building a flexible system becomes important.

sections.heading: When this verdict might flip
sections.content: If you quickly move from simple lists to wanting tasks linked with detailed notes and custom views, Notion may justify its setup time.

sections.heading: Quick decision rules
rules: If you want to start immediately, choose Todoist.
If designing a system feels overwhelming, avoid Notion.
If you plan to build a connected workspace later, Notion may fit better.

faqs.q: Does Notion require setup before tasks?
faqs.a: You usually create a page or database before tasks feel organized.

faqs.q: Is Todoist ready to use instantly?
faqs.a: Yes, you can begin adding tasks as soon as you open it.

faqs.q: Which app has fewer initial decisions?
faqs.a: Todoist has fewer upfront choices because it centers on simple lists.
It can, but its flexibility often invites customization that adds setup steps.
